Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Engineering cellular clearance pathways using nanoparticles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1254318
Segatori

Nanoparticles are now being engineered for a variety of important applications, ranging form diagnostics and therapeutics to energy production and materials. A number of nanoparticles of different size, shape and composition enter the cell through endocytosis and activate cellular clearance mechanisms and, particularly, autophagy, which is the main catabolic pathway that eliminates cellular waste and foreign material. Interestingly, impaired or inefficient autophagic activity is linked to accumulation of cellular waste material and development of a number of cancers, ageing and metabolic diseases. The project team recently developed a set of analytical tools to quantify the cellular clearance capacity and cell model systems to measure the accumulation of cellular waste. The overall research goal of the proposed project is to engineer the cellular clearance pathway using nanoparticles. To achieve this goal, the research team will identify nanoparticles that enhance clearance of toxic cellular waste material and will use these nanoparticles to investigate the molecular mechanism involved in regulation of autophagy. This study will lay the groundwork for developing novel therapeutic strategies to treat pathologic conditions associated with autophagy dysfunction, ranging from ageing and metabolic diseases to cancer.

This research project will provide the basis for the development of educational and training platforms, with the ultimate educational goal of diversifying the pool of students interested in biomolecular engineering and of increasing the retention of underrepresented groups - particularly girls and women - in STEM disciplines. To this end, the project integrates educational objectives relevant to high school students, undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty.

This CAREER award is co-funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) through the Instrument Development for Biological Research (IDBR) program, and by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanosized particles are ubiquitous in both natural and anthropogenic environments, and nanoparticles are now being used in a variety of important applications, ranging form diagnostics and therapeutics to energy production and materials. To date, however, surprisingly little is known about the interaction of nanoparticles with biological systems and about the potential health risks associated with the manufacture and use of nanoparticles. Given the recent advancement of nanotechnology for the development of novel therapeutic and diagnostic nanoparticles-based modalities, it is critical that these risks be identified and the impact of nanoparticles on cells fully elucidated to ensure safe use of nanotechnology.

Of special concern is the effect that nanoparticles have on cellular clearance systems. Nanoparticles of different size, shape and composition activate cellular clearance mechanisms, suggesting an attempt by the cell to dispose of what it perceives to be foreign material. Specifically, nanoparticles can activate autophagy, the main catabolic pathway that eliminates cellular waste and foreign material. Interestingly, extensive autophagic activity is linked to induction of cell death programs, suggesting the existence of a pro-death autophagy pathway in addition to the well documented pro- survival autophagy pathway. This observation raises significant biological questions regarding the nature of the molecular switch between pro-survival and pro-death autophagy. In addition, impairment of autophagy is linked to accumulation of cellular waste material and development of a number of cancers, ageing and metabolic diseases. In this study, we characterized the impact of different type of nanoparticles on the autophagy system to identify nanoparticles that activate the cellular clearance network, identify the cellular network that underlies the regulation of autophagy-associated cell death; and identify nanoparticles that enhance clearance of toxic cellular waste material.

The bionanotechnology approaches explored as part of the present study provided the basis for the development of educational and training platforms, with the ultimate educational goal of diversifying the pool of students interested in biomolecular engineering and of increasing the retention of underrepresented groups – particularly girls and women – in STEM disciplines. To this end, the project integrated educational objectives relevant to high school students, undergraduate students, graduate students, and even faculty. Specifically, it provided research opportunities to underrepresented high school students in science and provided a platform to collaborate with the Nuclear Power Institute ?POWER SET program to develop a Summer Bionanotechnology Camp and engage high school girls living in the rural, economically deprived, majority-minority communities of ?South Texas in the field of bionanotechnology. This project also contributed to improve teaching and learning for both undergraduate and graduate students, by designing new educational modules for existing undergraduate courses to enrich the biomolecular engineering component of the curriculum, and by leveraging Rice University’s rich nanotechnology community to develop a new graduate course focused specifically on the impact of nanotechnologies on human health, thereby filling an important gap in both science and in the nanotechnology workforce. Finally the PI contributed to building the biomolecular engineering community by serving as research mentor for the IRISE program that enables students from underrepresented groups to work in interdisciplinary fields, and by working with the Rice Office of Faculty Development to develop departmental and university workshops for future faculty to increase the competitiveness and diversity of candidates for academic positions.
